Award.AwardTitle: Specific Interactions of the Ribosome with the Nascent Peptide

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Regulation of gene expression is critical for cell survival. How gene expression is affected by the functioning of the ribosome machinery that translates genes into proteins remains poorly understood. The goals of the current proposal are to understand how genetically programmed translation effects control gene expression in bacteria. The findings are anticipated to significantly expand knowledge of the role of the ribosome in controlling gene expression and its functions as a small molecule sensor, and provide insights into cellular responses to changing environments. This knowledge will improve our understanding of fundamental principles of gene regulation and protein synthesis, and potentially open new avenues for controlling gene expression. The project will also help enrich the curriculum for Pharmacy professional and graduate students taught by PI and Co-PI, provide opportunities to expand training of high school students and increasing their interest in STEM disciplines. Additionally, the project will enable involvement of graduate students in outreach activities such as helping organize science fairs in inner-city schools with large minority student populations, participating in the Science Club of the True Value Boys and Girls Club in the Pilsen neighborhood of Chicago, which has a largely Hispanic population, or running workshops within the Expanding Your Horizons (EYH) network that helps to expose middle school girls to STEM activities and careers.

There is growing appreciation of the potential of the ribosome and its interactions with the nascent polypeptide to play a critical role in gene expression. However, the molecular mechanisms of nascent peptide recognition by the ribosome, the spectrum of translation events that may be tuned by the nascent protein, and the extent of gene regulation by nascent peptides remain poorly understood. One goal of the proposal is to understand, at the molecular level, the operation of programmed frameshifting that controls expression of a bacterial copper ion transporter gene, with special emphasis on the role of stimulatory elements encoded in the messenger RNA and, most importantly, in the nascent peptide. The second goal is to gain fundamental insights into the phenomenon of slow termination, which is prevalent in the bacterial genomes but affects only a specific subset of genes. Genome scale and biochemical approaches, especially involving the recently developed innovative Ribo-T system, will be used to advance these goals.

This project is funded jointly by the Genetic Mechanisms Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, Directorate for Biological Sciences, and the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems, Directorate for Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is usually assumed that each gene in the genomes of organisms encode one protein. But in reality, bacteria exploit various strategies to use a single gene to code for more than one protein. In the proposal funded by NSF, we have examined several strategies that bacteria use to increase the number of protein types expressed in their cells without increasing the size of their genomic DNA.  These strategies rely on the ability of the ribosome, the protein synthesis machine of the cell, to read the genetic message in an unconventional way, to exploit the alternative start signals in the genes and to use its interactions with the protein it makes to regulate protein synthesis. Two strategies examined in our work, that allow production more than one protein from a single gene, are ?programmed frameshifting? and ?alternative start site selection?.

In the first strategy, bacterial ribosome can switch the register in which it reads the genetic message, thereby generating two proteins that are the same at the beginning but are different at their ends. Often, one of the proteins is long and the other is truncated. We have shown that some bacteria exploit this strategy when they express proteins from the copA gene which is involved in maintaining proper concentration of the metal copper in bacteria. We showed that production of both, a long and a short protein is needed for the correct operation of the copper-controlling machinery. How much of each protein is produced depends on the interaction of the ribosome with the genetic message and with the protein the ribosome makes. Importantly, some human diseases are caused by wrong concentration of copper in the human cells resulting from incorrect production of similar proteins. Therefore, our findings may inform future development of better medicines.

We further discovered that bacteria often use an opposite strategy for making more than one protein from a single gene: in this case they produce proteins which are the same at their ends but differ at their beginning.  This strategy utilizes two different start sites for protein synthesis in the gene. The discovery of how widespread this strategy in bacteria became possible due to the development of a new method, which we called Ribo-RET, that allows for mapping start sites of protein-coding genes across the bacterial genomes. Applying this method to a model bacteria, E. coli, we showed that many genes are ?read? by the ribosome from more than one start sites, thereby, generating two or more proteins. We also showed that at least in some cases, production of two proteins from one gene through this strategy is important for correct operation of biochemical circuits in the cell.

The work on the project opened new opportunities for disseminating science to a broad public and increase interest in STEM branches of science among school kids and university students with a special emphasis on the population groups traditionally underrepresented in science. Among many activities that the project helped to carry out were the following: participating over several years of the PIs and their students in the Expanding Your Horizons workshop for middle school girls from Chicago inner-city schools; presentations of the PIs at the Career days in Chicago public schools (e.g. Talcott Elementary School) and Community colleges (e.g. Harold Washington Community College of Chicago); participating and judging Science Fairs in Chicago public schools (e.g. the Gonsalus Academy School); volunteering of the graduate students in Boys and Girls Club of Chicago in Pilsen, the Chicago neighborhood with many Hispanic children, and many others. The project allowed to provide continuous support for the high school student summer internship program (SPARK) of the Stephenson High school, through which one to two high-school students have been carrying out research every summer through the entire duration of the NSF-funded project. The work on the project allowed training a number of undergraduate and professional students, both by the PIs and by the graduate students involved in the project.

The findings of the project has been disseminated to the broad scientific community through publication of the results in the leading scientific journals, presentations at the local, regional and International scientific forums. Our discoveries have been also made known to general public, because many of the published papers have been reflected in the press-releases, discussed in blogs, and highlighted in the commentaries published on-line and in press.
